question: What should Wyoming drivers know about wind?
optionA: Wind gusts mainly affect motorcycles so larger vehicles like trucks and RVs can maintain normal speeds
optionB: High winds are common statewide and can affect control especially for high-profile vehicles
optionC: Mountain passes see occasional gusts but the open plains and valleys remain calm most of the year
optionD: Seasonal wind advisories apply only during spring months when storms move through the region

question: What is Mississippi cell phone law for teen drivers?
optionA: Hands-free devices are required for all drivers including teens with learner permits statewide
optionB: No texting for anyone and no phone use at all for permit and intermediate license holders
optionC: Same rules as adult drivers apply once a teen completes the graduated licensing program
optionD: Complete ban on all electronic devices including GPS and music apps for drivers under eighteen

question: Are right turns on red permitted in Massachusetts?
optionA: Right turns on red are never permitted anywhere in Boston including signed intersections citywide
optionB: Yes unless prohibited and Boston prohibits right on red unless signs specifically allow it
optionC: Always permitted at any intersection after coming to a complete stop and yielding to traffic
optionD: Only permitted when a green arrow signal is displayed indicating the turn is protected

question: What should drivers know about New York City driving?
optionA: Standard driving rules apply throughout all five boroughs with normal speed enforcement
optionB: Extensive regulations including no right on red alternate side parking and congestion pricing
optionC: Same rules as the rest of New York State apply with slightly lower posted speed limits in boroughs
optionD: Lower speed limits and metered parking are the only differences from upstate driving rules

question: Who can supervise a Vermont permit holder?
optionA: Any licensed adult driver over the age of 21 can supervise regardless of their driving experience
optionB: Licensed driver 25 or older with 3 years experience or a parent or guardian with 1 year
optionC: Anyone over 21 with a valid license and at least 6 months of driving experience in Vermont
optionD: Only parents or legal guardians may supervise and they must hold a valid Vermont license

question: What is unique about Wisconsin motorcycle rules for drivers?
optionA: No special motorcycle awareness rules exist beyond standard right-of-way laws for all vehicles
optionB: Drivers must be aware of motorcycle-friendly laws and know that lane filtering is not permitted
optionC: Lane splitting is allowed for motorcycles at speeds under 25 mph in congested traffic conditions
optionD: Helmets are optional for all motorcycle riders over 18 regardless of experience or license type

question: What is open range in Wyoming?
optionA: Open range laws were repealed in 2015 so all livestock must now be fenced by property owners
optionB: Livestock may be on unfenced roads and drivers are responsible for avoiding collisions
optionC: Open range applies only on private ranch land and livestock must be fenced near public highways
optionD: All major highways are fenced but county roads may have occasional livestock crossing areas

question: What should Nevada drivers know about Las Vegas area traffic?
optionA: Standard highway rules apply and traffic flows smoothly due to the grid street design

question: What should Michigan drivers know about deer?
optionA: Deer are not a significant concern because Michigan has wildlife fencing along major highways
optionB: Michigan has high deer-vehicle collision rates especially from October through December
optionC: Deer crossings are only marked in designated park areas and rural recreation zones
optionD: Marked wildlife crossing zones with reduced speed limits alert drivers to all deer areas

question: What should Montana drivers know about winter driving?
optionA: Winters are relatively mild compared to other northern states due to Chinook wind patterns
optionB: Severe winters with snow ice and limited visibility require strong winter driving skills
optionC: Snowfall is rare in the eastern plains though mountain passes may close during major storms
optionD: Tire chains are always required by law on all vehicles from November through March statewide

question: What should Massachusetts drivers know about Boston area driving?
optionA: Standard urban conditions apply with typical traffic patterns found in any northeastern city
optionB: Rotaries complex intersections and aggressive traffic require extra attention from drivers
optionC: No special concerns exist because road improvements have modernized most Boston intersections

question: What should Virginia drivers know about reckless driving?
optionA: Reckless driving is handled the same as other states with standard fines and points assessed
optionB: Speeds over 85 mph or 20 over the limit is reckless driving which is a criminal offense
optionC: Reckless driving charges only apply in school zones and designated construction areas

question: What are zipper merges in Minnesota?
optionA: Zipper merges are not officially recognized and drivers should merge as early as possible
optionB: Encouraged method where drivers use all lanes and merge at the designated merge point
optionC: Zipper merging is considered an illegal maneuver and can result in a failure to yield citation
optionD: Zipper merging rules only apply to commercial trucks and buses during construction zones

question: How many passengers can a Pennsylvania junior driver carry in first 6 months?
optionA: No passenger limits apply as long as all occupants are wearing seat belts in available seats
optionB: No more passengers than seat belts and no more than 1 under 18 unless family member
optionC: Maximum of 2 passengers regardless of age are permitted during the first six months
optionD: Only immediate family members may ride as passengers for the entire first year period

question: What happens if you drive without insurance in Texas?
optionA: First offense results in a written warning with no fine if you obtain insurance within 30 days
optionB: Fines up to $350 for first offense plus surcharges and possible license suspension
optionC: Points are added to your driving record but no fine is assessed until the second offense occurs
optionD: A small fine under $100 is typical for first-time offenders with no additional penalties

question: What should Texas drivers know about frontage roads?
optionA: Frontage roads do not exist in Texas because highways use standard entrance and exit ramp designs
optionB: Frontage roads run parallel to highways with unique entrance and exit patterns to learn
optionC: Frontage roads follow the same rules as regular surface streets with no special considerations

question: What should Utah drivers know about inversions?
optionA: Inversions are not a driving concern in Utah because they primarily affect air quality only

question: What should Washington drivers know about ferries?
optionA: Washington does not operate a state ferry system and all ferry routes are privately managed

optionC: Ferry service is available through private operators only and is not part of the state system

optionA: No passenger restrictions apply once the intermediate license is issued to the teenage driver

question: What is unique about North Dakota oil field areas?
optionA: Oil field development has not significantly impacted road conditions or traffic in the region
